text: Apparently the Canadian government has an open science roadmap including recommendations like: ‘*Federal departments and agencies should conduct intradepartmental consultations with the science community before June 2020 to seek feedback on, and address in the action plan, the challenges and opportunities of Open Science. These should be led by the Department’s Open Science Champion(s), e.g., Departmental Science Advisor, Chief Science Officer, Assistant Deputy Minister and Vice President Science’.* Unluckily, this was published Feb 2020, so I don’t think much has happened so far… :eyes: <https://www.ic.gc.ca/eic/site/063.nsf/eng/h_97992.html>

attachments.title: Roadmap for Open Science - Science.gc.ca
attachments.text: This Roadmap outlines next steps that should be taken to make federal science open to all, while respecting privacy, security, ethical considerations and appropriate intellectual property protection.

elements.text: Apparently the Canadian government has an open science roadmap including recommendations like: ‘

Federal departments and agencies should conduct intradepartmental consultations with the science community before June 2020 to seek feedback on, and address in the action plan, the challenges and opportunities of Open Science. These should be led by the Department’s Open Science Champion(s), e.g., Departmental Science Advisor, Chief Science Officer, Assistant Deputy Minister and Vice President Science’.
Unluckily, this was published Feb 2020, so I don’t think much has happened so far…

text: Cool! Just skimmed over it, but it’s nice there’s a federal push for this. If it’s implemented intelligently this could be a good way to start moving Canadian research and education towards open science practices :)

elements.text: Cool! Just skimmed over it, but it’s nice there’s a federal push for this. If it’s implemented intelligently this could be a good way to start moving Canadian research and education towards open science practices :)

text: I figured I’d ask here in case anyone has done this before, but have you worked with likert scale data where there are straightliners (people who answer the same thing or develop a pattern of responses to get it done quicker)? If so, how do you personally find them without just visually looking at the individual data?

elements.text: I figured I’d ask here in case anyone has done this before, but have you worked with likert scale data where there are straightliners (people who answer the same thing or develop a pattern of responses to get it done quicker)? If so, how do you personally find them without just visually looking at the individual data?

text:
For someone giving the same answer every time you could use that unique() function in R I showed you last week, iterated over each participant, and then flag any participant with only one unique response. I think you said SPSS had a similar function so you might be able to do it there too.

A pattern of responses would be much harder to identify programatically. I haven’t done this before, but essentially you’d have to take a portion of their responses, then test it against other sections of their responses for matches. I wouldn’t even bother trying this unless someone has code for it already available. But maybe to make manual search easier you could make a scatterplot of each participant’s responses (so one plot per participant), then it would be fairly easy to see any patterned responses. I think this would be pretty straightforward to do in R.
